titles.en: Chapter 55 – The merits of the meat

titles.ar: باب الْأَسْوِقَةِ وَ فَضْلِ سَوِيقِ الْحِنْطَةِ
titles.en: Chapter 53 – The Suweyq (flour soup) and the preference of the Suweyq of wheat

gradings: Allamah Baqir al-Majlisi: مجهول مرفوع - Mir‘at al ‘Uqul Fi Sharh Akhbar Al al Rasul (22/126)

parts.text: أَبِي عَبْدِ اللَّهِ ( عليه السلام ) أَنَّهُ

narrator_chain.text: مُحَمَّدُ بْنُ يَحْيَى عَنْ مُحَمَّدِ بْنِ مُوسَى رَفَعَهُ عَنْ أَبِي عَبْدِ اللَّهِ ( عليه السلام ) أَنَّهُ قَالَ

text: سَوِيقُ الْعَدَسِ يَقْطَعُ الْعَطَشَ وَ يُقَوِّي الْمَعِدَةَ وَ فِيهِ شِفَاءٌ مِنْ سَبْعِينَ دَاءً وَ يُطْفِئُ الصَّفْرَاءَ وَ يُبَرِّدُ الْجَوْفَ وَ كَانَ إِذَا سَافَرَ ( عليه السلام ) لَا يُفَارِقُهُ وَ كَانَ يَقُولُ ( عليه السلام ) إِذَا هَاجَ الدَّمُ بِأَحَدٍ مِنْ حَشَمِهِ قَالَ لَهُ اشْرَبْ مِنْ سَوِيقِ الْعَدَسِ فَإِنَّهُ يُسَكِّنُ هَيَجَانَ الدَّمِ وَ يُطْفِئُ الْحَرَارَةَ .

en.hubeali: Muhammad Bin Yahya, from Muhammad Bin Musa, raising it,

(It has been narrated) from Abu Abdullah<sup>asws</sup> having said: ‘Suweyq of the lentils cuts the thirst, and strengthens the stomach, and in it is a healing from seventy illnesses, and it extinguishes the yellowness and is a coolness for the interior; and it was that whenever he<sup>asws</sup> travelled, did not separate from it, and he<sup>asws</sup> was saying: ‘Whenever someone’s blood of modesty got agitated, he<sup>asws</sup> said to him: ‘Drink the Suweyq of lentils, for it would settle the agitation of the blood and extinguish the heat’.
en.sarwar: 1. Muhammad ibn Yahya has narrated from Muhammad ibn Musa in a marfu‘ manner has said, the following: “Abu ‘ Abd Allah, ‘Alayhi al-Salam, has said, sawiq of lintels calms down thirst, makes the stomach strong and there is cure for seventy illnesses in it. It abolishes yellowish fluid and gives coolness to the stomach. He (the Imam) would not travel without it. He (the Imam) said that when blood becomes excited with any of one’s associates, he (the Imam) said, ‘Drink sawiq of lintels because it calms down the excitement of blood and extinguishes the heat.’”*

gradings: Allamah Baqir al-Majlisi: صحيح - Mir‘at al ‘Uqul Fi Sharh Akhbar Al al Rasul (22/127)

narrator_chain.text: وَ عَنْهُ عَنْ مُحَمَّدِ بْنِ عِيسَى عَنْ عَلِيِّ بْنِ مَهْزِيَارَ قَالَ

text: إِنَّ جَارِيَةً لَنَا أَصَابَهَا الْحَيْضُ وَ كَانَ لَا يَنْقَطِعُ عَنْهَا حَتَّى أَشْرَفَتْ عَلَى الْمَوْتِ فَأَمَرَ أَبُو جَعْفَرٍ ( عليه السلام ) أَنْ تُسْقَى سَوِيقَ الْعَدَسِ فَسُقِيَتْ فَانْقَطَعَ عَنْهَا وَ عُوفِيَتْ .

en.hubeali: And from him, from Muhammad Bin Isa, from Ali Bin Mahziyar who said,

‘A slave girls of our was hit by the menstruation, and it would not get cut-off from her until she came near the death. So Abu Ja’far<sup>asws</sup> ordered that she should be made to drink the Suweyq of lentils. So she was made to drink it, so it got cut-off from her, and she recovered’.
en.sarwar: 2. It is narrated from the narrator of the previous Hadith from Muhammad ibn ‘Isa from Ali ibn Mahziyar from who has said the following: “We had a girl whose Hayd (menses) would not stop and she was about to die. Abu Ja’far, ‘Alayhi al- Salam, instructed to make her drink sawiq of lintels. She used the drink, bleeding stop and she was cured.’”

gradings: Allamah Baqir al-Majlisi: ضعيف - Mir‘at al ‘Uqul Fi Sharh Akhbar Al al Rasul (22/127)

narrator_chain.text: عِدَّةٌ مِنْ أَصْحَابِنَا عَنْ سَهْلِ بْنِ زِيَادٍ عَنِ السَّيَّارِيِّ عَنْ إِبْرَاهِيمَ بْنِ بِسْطَامَ عَنْ رَجُلٍ مِنْ أَهْلِ مَرْوَ قَالَ

text: بَعَثَ إِلَيْنَا الرِّضَا ( عليه السلام ) وَ هُوَ عِنْدَنَا يَطْلُبُ السَّوِيقَ فَبَعَثْنَا إِلَيْهِ بِسَوِيقٍ مَلْتُوتٍ فَرَدَّهُ وَ بَعَثَ إِلَيَّ أَنَّ السَّوِيقَ إِذَا شُرِبَ عَلَى الرِّيقِ وَ هُوَ جَافٌّ أَطْفَأَ الْحَرَارَةَ وَ سَكَّنَ الْمِرَّةَ وَ إِذَا لُتَّ لَمْ يَفْعَلْ ذَلِكَ .

en.hubeali: A number of our companions, from Sahl Bin Ziyad, from Al Sayyari, from Ibrahim Bin Bustan, form a man from the people of Marv who said,

‘Al-Reza<sup>asws</sup> sent a messenger and he<sup>asws</sup> was seeking Al-Suweyq which was with us. So we sent it over to him<sup>asws</sup> a mixture of Suweyq. So he<sup>asws</sup> returned it and sent a message to us that Al-Suweyq, when it is drunk upon the empty stomach, and it is dry, it extinguished the heat and settles the bile; and when it is mixed, it does not do that’.
en.sarwar: 3. A number of our people have narrated from Sahl ibn Ziyad from al-Sayyariy from Ibrahim ibn Bitam from a man of the people of Marv who has said the following: “Abu al-Hassan, al-Rida’, ‘Alayhi al-Salam, once sent to us someone asking for sawiq and we sent to him (the Imam) sawiq mixed with ghee or oil. He (the Imam) returned it saying, ‘If one takes dry sawiq before breakfast it dispels temperature, calms down bitterness but when it is mixed it then does not have that effect.’”
